stem: Following compression of the radial nerve in the distal arm, which combined deficit pattern is most characteristic?

choices.A: Wrist drop with sensory loss over lateral dorsum of hand/digits 1â€“3
choices.B: Loss of shoulder abduction with lateral shoulder numbness
choices.C: Inability to oppose the thumb with thenar atrophy
choices.D: Ulnar deviation on wrist flexion and numbness in digit 5
choices.E: Weak forearm pronation and palm numbness sparing thenar skin

rationale_correct: Distal radial lesions classically cause wrist/digit extensor weakness (wrist drop) and sensory deficits over the lateral dorsal hand.

rationale_distractors.B: Axillary nerve lesion (surgical neck of humerus) causes deltoid weakness and lateral shoulder paresthesia.
rationale_distractors.C: Median nerve/recurrent motor lesion (thenar) not radial.
rationale_distractors.D: Findings of ulnar lesions (FCU/FDP medial) not radial.
rationale_distractors.E: Pronator syndrome (median) can spare thenar skin due to palmar cutaneous branch.

evidence.citation: Selski D. Nerve Injuries of the Upper Limb Lecture Notes. Sep 22, 2025.
